Knowing their own strength, they Avere inspired with confidence, but a confidence that made them judge for themselves, and proceed on their march by slow journeys, as their humour prompted. The cavalry and auxiliary cohorts came forward with more alacrity. The troops that marched from Rome were a formidable body. They consisted of five praetorian cohorts, several squadrons of horse, and the first legion. To these were added two thousand gladiators; a resource altogether ignoble, but"in civil commotions often employed by generals of the first reputation. AnniusG alius and Vestricius Spurinna (b) were sent at the head of this whole force, with orders to take post on the banks of the Po. The first intention was to keep the enemy locked up in Gaul; but that project proved abor- tive, Caecina having already passed the Alps.
